Award.AwardTitle: Host Tolerance and Resistance: Applying Ecological Concepts to the Dynamics of Parasite-Host Infections
Award.AbstractNarration:
Individuals vary in their response to natural enemies and this variation has an important effect on the relationship between consumers and resources. Animals and plants can tolerate or resist the attacks of their enemies and enemies must shape their attack strategies to optimize survival and reproduction. A challenge in the ecology of species interactions is to identify the factors responsible for this individual variation. At the heart of host-parasite interactions lie the immunological processes that allow the host to respond to an infection and the life history strategies that allow parasites to escape host immune defenses and to maximize survival and transmission. This interdisciplinary project integrates recent progress in the immunology of tolerance and resistance with the theory of food web dynamics to examine how the contrasting responses of tolerance and resistance influence parasite development and fecundity within hosts and how these responses affect transmission and long term persistence at host population level. The investigators aim to develop one of the first population-level studies of tolerance-resistance as defined at the molecular level. This will be achieved by a combination of detailed laboratory studies, field monitoring and mathematical modeling.

By identifying the molecular bases for species interactions, this project will provide novel insights into host-parasite interactions and will enhance understanding of community structure, food web dynamics and biodiversity. Parasites represent serious health and economic threats for animals and humans and an appreciation of the fundamental processes of host-parasite interaction will accelerate development of alternative measures for parasite control. Finally, this highly interdisciplinary study offers numerous opportunities to train graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral researchers in multidisciplinary, quantitative approaches and analyses.

Intellectual Merit

Individual responses to natural enemies can generate two types of reactions: individuals can resist the attacks or tolerate the presence of these enemies. A challenge in the ecology of species interactions is to understand what determines these contrasting responses. For hosts infected with parasites understanding the mechanisms of tolerance and resistance requires an appreciation of how the host immune system responds to the infection and how parasites adjust to optimize survival and fecundity.

This study examined how parasite dynamics were affected by within host processes; specifically, how within-host resource competition and host immunity influence transmission and long-term persistence at the host population level. The impact of external disturbance, such as anti-parasite drug treatment and climate change were also investigated. Field studies and laboratory experiments were undertaken using two common gastrointestinal parasites of the rabbit (Trichostrongylus retortaeformis and Graphidium strigosum) and mathematical models were developed to describe host-parasite interactions at the within-host and the host population level. 

Within-host dynamics of infection

We developed a model framework that links within-host parasite dynamics (parasite intensity and mortality) and parasite life-history traits (development and fecundity). Many previous studies have used either cross-sectional data (i.e. worms/host), which fails to capture individual host variation through time, or longitudinal data (i.e. parasite eggs in feces/time), which fails to directly observe parasite intensity. Our novel statistical framework combines both data sources to overcome the limitations of each and uses laboratory trials where hosts were treated with an anti-parasite drug half way the trial. We showed that:

  1. The two parasites exhibit different dynamics within the rabbits: T. retortaeformis intensity increases before being cleared by the host immune system, consistent with a resistance response; G. strigosum intensity, however, is not limited despite a clear immune response, consistent with tolerance.
  2. The mean and maximum T. retortaeformis intensity was not different before and after anti-parasite treatment. However, parasites were shorter, females produce fewer eggs and fewer eggs were shed in the environment following drug treatment. Thus, parasite transmission is limited by changes in parasite life-history rather that the intensity of infection. The immune response produced against the infection supported a resistant response by the rabbit.
  3. Similarly, for G. strigosum we found that intensity is not different before and after drug treatment and worm length is shorter post-treatment. However, parasites continue accumulating in the rabbits without clear evidence of host control. While we have evidence of a resistant immune response, worms appear to have developed strategies to avoid or cope with these assaults.  

Host population dynamics of infection

The epidemiology of infection was examined using a natural population of rabbits sampled monthly for 23-years. For each parasite species we examined how between-host variation in the immune response altered the impact of climate-driven parasite infections. The interaction of immunity and climatic factors has been rarely addressed in models of disease dynamics and climate change. Immunity can mitigate disease severity by increasing resistance to re-infection, in contrast, hosts that lack a strong immune response, and tolerate the infection, should be expected to have more worms.
